The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at TOR (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8:30 a.m. in time for Express Switzerland, Paris and London leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9.30 a.m. and are conveyed direcly to Quay alongside steamer.

Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.

Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.

The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette The English Daily newspaper, Established 1880. Editor and Manager - R. SMELLING Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF. MONDAY, JULY 30, 1908.
MUSTAPHA KAMEL IN LONDON.
div.p: The visit of Mustapha Pasha Kamel to London i-i symptomatic of the ohange that has been brought about by the Anglo-French Agreement. A few years ago the "Egyptian Patriot" woald not have ventured to visit London in his official <araoity as the month- piece of Egyptian Nationalism. Bat London now a-days ofTars a far wider scope to this gentleman than the French Capital oan. Only a few days ago the "Figaro" warned any o< its readers, who might be likely to sympathise with the Pasha's aspirations, that they were approaching dangerous ground by so doing, inasmuch as any flirtation With Pan Islamic ideas would only be an encouragement tr malcontents in Algeria and Tunis, and that i behoved England and Franoe, in view of their interests in Northern Africa, to offer a firm stand against each a dangerous formofpo'itica) propaganda.

The French have, in faot, become rather wea(y of this ydnug man's Agent harangnea against England in Egypt, and fail to see the utility of countenancing his intrigaes; especially as they have to gh^ern a vast Moslem population. He has con&qqaent'y tamed Lie attention to London, ana\rom all accounts appears to be very energetic. r(e has written letters to the "Standard" and tubs? Tribune been the gaest of the evening at a yegeptioo of the Pan-Islamio Society, and entertained to a Innch at the Carlton Hotel a unmber of" M..P.s and also oce member of the Upper Hoase, Lord Lyttoo, whose only connection with Egypt appears to be that his brother is the sou-in-law of Mr. Wilfred Blant. It had been expected that about thirty M.P.'s would have accepted the Pasha's invitation. Mr. Byles made his excuses this time, but among M.P.'s present were Mr. J. M. Robertson, M.P. for the Tyneside division of Northumberland ; Mr. J. F. Boland, M.P. for Sonth Kerry j and Mr. Fnllerton, the Liberal Labour M.P. for We t Cumberland. Herr Karl Blind was also among the guests.

Afterwards Mastapha Pasha Kamel declaim ed against the "errors and lies" wh;ch are spread alMover Bogtand about his oonntry. "The hamniation of a whole country and a whole race by a more than barbarous execu­tion," he said, "is not sufficient for the rnlers of Egypt. They mast throw discredit on the Egyptian nation. The real movement in Egypt is a national one. The Egyptian people want independence. The Sudan, tha soul of our oonntry, has been sna'ched from ns by English politicians."

Elsewhere we give a report of theepeecb which the Editor of "Al Lewa" gave to bis gneets. No doabt the European population in Egypt will be surprised that the Pasha could have collected a unmber of M.P.'s together to listen to his Anglophobe harangue. Bat after an excellent Innch at the Carlton it does not matter much what oratory follows, and as nlost of the Labour and Nationalist guests of the Pasha were probably incapable of following his fluent French it is charitable to suppose that the greater part of the speech was incom­prehensible to those present. The spokesman of the guests, the M. P. for Tyneiide, appears to have been gaarded in his words. He de­clared that "the Egyptian Nationalists shoo/d be frank and open in their demands, and if they aoted with prndenoe and patience, they might one day secure the blessing of the giaranteed independence of Egypt" The meaning of the latter phrase is really on a par with Lord Cromer's declaration that "al­though it may take a long time to arrive at Egyptian autonomy, that antonomy is the ultimate goal towards which reform should gradually be directed."

That the visit of the Pasha will have any results we do not for one moment believe. Not a single person of any weight in the political world was among his gnests, and the fact that Mr. Byles failed to attend is curiously signi­ficant. It is worth while, however, to remind oar Liberal contemporaries on the London Press, who may be prone to listen to our oon- fr^re's persuasive eloquence, that any support they may be Refined to give him is tant­amount to a Tnrcophile policy in Egypt and tfie Near East. As soon as the Little Euglan ier wing of the present Government grasp tbia obvious faot, they will leavp Mnstapha Pasha Kamel severely alone, for although they may detest Imperialism, they detest the Saltan far more, and all the propaganda of the "Egyptian Patriot" is merely directed towards the re­establishment of the political power of the Caliph in Egypt and the Sudan.

div.head: ENGLAND AND TURKEY.
div.p: For a few hoars last week there was (a Constantinople correspondent relates) every appearance of a fresh * incident" between Eng­land »nd Turkey, but, happily, it has all been settled satisfactorily.

Early on Thursday morning a number of police and soldiers saddenly surrounded an English ooal store, and allowed no one to enter or approaoh it Tha Consulate, on being appealed to, sent a representative to the spot, but he conld only find ont that an iradl had baen issaed, though no one knew the reason. The Consulate applied to the Minister of Police, and next day it was discovered that some months ago a meichant had bought a quantity of old iron from the Admiralty, amongst which was an old gun, broken np, and had placed it in a store called the Tiftik Hane, previous to shipping it to England. Meanwhile, somebody reported that the Admiralty were selling gans, which were bsing taken to the Tiftik Hane Mohair Store, and an irad£ was immediately issaed ordering the store* at Tiftik Hane to be searched. Unfortunately, Turkish is a difficult language to write, and, in the order, a single dot wai omitted, so that it read "the store at Tewfeak Hane Gan Store." The □olioe therefore raided the only store near the Tewfenk Hane, which happened to be a ooal store.
Oq this being explained, proper apologies were made, and the incident was closed. It reminds one of the confusion that arose be­tween Tabah and Dab ah, owing to the omission if a dot.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: To-day's plague bulletin records two fresh sees at Suez and a death at Alexandria, udan Rains.
Bountiful rains are reported from the Khar­tum distriot, and are ielaying communications, ublio Health Dept
M. Habib Hanna, physician, and M. Petro Ivanguel, pharmacist, have been authorised to raotise in Egypt.
he Survey.
Survey work in Upper Egypt is nearly nished, and is now commencing in the Mon- irieh of Gharbieh.
eeondary Sohool for Alexandria.
The Ministry of Finance has opened a oredit f L.E. 50,000 for the establishment of a eeondary sohool in Alexandria.
xeoutlon at Tantah.
Abd el Samad Khalifa, a native of Fara- ihoot, Gharbieh, found guilty of murder, was xeoated this morning in Tantah prison.
lurder Enquiry.
MuBtapha Maher Bey, Moudir of Minieh, is kt Fashn, and has opeued an enquiry into the nurder of the moaw'.n of the railway Btation. .ote Turns.
The Imperial Ottoman Bank informs ns that he "gros lot" in yesterday's drawing of Otto- nan Railway Lottery bonds was won by the miderofbond No. 1,630,812.
lashish Smuggling.

On the 29th ult. the Coast Guards con- iscated 190 kilos of hashish in a boat, specially kdapted for hashish smuggling, which was also tonfiseated, near Ismai'ia. The smugglers were isken into onstody.
'olios Circular.

'The Gouvernorat of Cairo has issued instruc­tors, by circular, to all the police kisms, as to what preliminary measures to adopt in the went of the death of a native, so as to de- iuitely dispose of his property.
(hedlvlal Law 8ohool.

The "Moayad" is given to understand that the Ministry of Public Instruction has decided to admit into the Kbedivial Law School, luring this coming session, a large number of graduates from the secondary schools.
The Cairo Fire.

The value of the loss sustained by Mr. Hassan Farag is estimated at L.E. 12,000. The building contained oils, paints, and iron­ware. Messrs. Antoun Rabbat owned the shop next door which was also destroyed. Pheir los es are valned at L.E. 3,COO.
Where were they going 7

A few days ago, says "Al Minbar," a patrol under the Hskamdar of Kalioubieh met with several natives, fully armed with guns and axes, going to some unknown destination in that moadirieh. The extraordinary gang were imprisoned, in accordance w?h instruc­tions from the Cairo Parquet.
Burled Alive.

Oar Suez Correspondent writes :—Yesterday (Tuesday) afternoon, while some native masons were demolishing an old house in the native quarter of Saez, the walls suddenly collapsed and buried Mustapha Abonlahm, who was killed on the spot. His body was subsequently recovered with great difficulty.
Esbekleh Theatre.

The bow term fixed by the Ministry of Pablio Works for the adjudication of the lease of this theatre for 1907 closed on Tuesday, July 31, the sole bidder being Mme. Santina. The previous term appointed for May was annulled owing to the criticism of the Press regarding the shortness of the time allowed— from Saturday to Wednesday.
Credits Opened.

The Finance Ministry has opened the fol­lowing credits : — L.E 4,000 for water mains dong the avenae to the Pyramids; L.E. 10,000 for irrigation works on the Gash river, Kassala province ; L.E. l.fOO for a survey of the Upper Nile between Lake Albert and Gon- dokoro; L.E. If0,000 for dredgers for the Sadan ; L.E. 1,200 for repairs to Saez harbour works.
Swiss National Fete.

The Swiss colony at Alexandria celebrated their Independence Day last night at the Beau Rivage Hotel, Ramleh, by a banquet | and a ball. The hotel's spaoious terrace was beautifully decorated and arranged for the occasion, there were over 100 guests, and a most enjoyable evening was spent by all present. An excellent sapper was served, and dancing was indalged in until an early hour this morning. The f6te was in every way a great sucoe s, and the arrangements made reflect the greatest oredit on the Beau- Rivage management.
New Employment Registry.

The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Ap­plications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: PAN ISLAMISM.
div.p: THE CALIPH'S ORDER.
A DANGEROUS SUBJECT.
( Gazette's Special Service, )
London, Thursday, August 2. The "Daily Telegraph's" Constantinople correspondent wires that the Sultan has given orders that all reference to Pan-Islamism in the local Press is to be forbidden.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE AT OSTEND.
div.p: The Khedive arrived at Ostend unexpec­tedly on Friday last. His Highness will visit successively Antwerp and Brussels, where he will be received officially by King Leopold. On leaving Belgium the Khedive will proceed to Kissingen in Germany for a course of the waters. He will eooupy apartments at a well- known establishment oondnoted by Professor Dapper.

div.head: TIIE BRITISH GARRISON.
div.p: The King's Own Scottish Borderers, at Hyderabad Barracks, Colchester, have received orders to hold themselves in readiness to proceed, it is thought, to Egypt.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: THE WORKMEN'S STRIKE.
The Alexandria Municipality has arrived at an understanding with its workmen and to­morrow work will be resnmed as usual.

An incident occurred at Miuet-el-Bassal this morning. The strikers went there to interview some of the "blacklegs," who still persisted in working. When one of the Btriksrs approach ed these men a policemen threatened him, a souffle ensued, and an Arab striker, named Mohamed R'chid, was arrested, and Gaetano Bernice, who tried to rescue him, was injured on the hand. The strikers afterwards went to the Italian Consulate, where the authorities enjoined them to refrain from acts of violence and promised that they would interest them selves on their beha'f. A meeting subsequently took place between the Italian Vice-Consol and Mr. Rie4i, of the Alexandria Municipal Council, and an acoord was arrived at. It was agreed to resnme work to morrow on the condition that the Municipality would enquire into the grievances of their petition for an increase cf wages in view of the enorm­ous and continuous inorease in the cost of the necessaries of life.

div.head: SUDAN AND ABYSSINIA.
div.p: According to "Al Zaher," the Abyssinians on the Sadan frontier have requested permis­sion of the Government to enter the Sudan. The Sudan Government has reassured that of Abyssinia, which was disturbed by the request of its sabjects.

The district of Beni has been annexed to the district of Kellabat, which depends from the Sadan Government. The revenue from this newly annexed district will be divided be­tween the Abyssinian and Sudanese Govern­ments.

div.head: AFFRAY AT PORT SUDAN.
div.p: An affray whioh, but for the prompt in­tervention of Bimhashi Parsons, the Governor, might have had serions results, occurred on the 17th ult. at a new village a mile or so west of Port Sadan. The place is occupied by Sadanese, who had built the vi'lages and were, as is their castom, digging wells, which were closely guarded from outsiders.

On the evening of the 17th several Haden- dawa approached one of the wells, but were ordered off by the ghaffir, whe trie! to seize the 8word of oue of the party. The ghaffir was kuocked down, and his cries attracted the villagers, who gave chase to the intruders, stoning them as they ran.

The Hadendowa, however, being reinforoed and numbering sixty, returned armed to the teeth and attacked their pnreners, with whom they wore well matched, and thanks to their weapons wonnded twenty-five of them, six Hadendowa ODly beirg hart.

It was at thia psychological moment, as the saying goes, that Bimbashi Parsons,* with a detachment of troops, police, and ghaffirs, arrived and promptly separated the warriors, and arrested those of them who ha I not been wonnded.

div.head: JUSTICE IN EGYPT. THE DENISHWAI EXECUTIONS. OFFICIAL CORRESPONDENCE. BRITISH PSEUDO-HUMANITARIANS.
div.p: WEIGHTY PROTEST.

A White Paper has been issued dealing with the recent ontrage upon British officers in Egypt, and with the subsequent executions at Denishwai. The correspondence is prefaced by a Khedivial decree, dated February, 1$95, which sets up a special tribunal for dealing with crimes committed by natives against officers or men of tie British Army of Occupation, or of any British warship stationed in an Egyptian port.

A report to Sir Edward Grey by the Earl of Cromer, dated June 15, states that the natives attaoked the officers with nabonts, or heavy ! sticks, and that the most serious attaok was made with these nabouts after the officers had been deprived of their guns, and were conse­quently defenceless. "This fact," he points ont, "shows a very hostile and determined spirit on the part of the villagers." A tele­gram from Mr. Findlay, our aoting Agent after Lord Cromer's departure, to Sir E. Grey, on June 22, states that even the anti-English Press speaks of the "olemenoy" of the officers attacked, and regards the oonduot of the vil­lagers as casting discredit on the whole Egyp­tian people, as well as being indefensible in itself.

A subsequent dispatch to Lord Cromer lays emphasis on the facts that the officers had gone to shoot by invitation, that the attack was probably premeditated, and that a small fire which broke ont on a threshing-floor (not in a granary, as previously stated), and which was at once extinguished, was probably a precon­certed signal for this attaok, and not the chief oanse of the exoitement. In Lord Cromer's view this premeditation against officers in uniform gives a very serions aspect to the incident.

A post-mortem examination made by the medioo-legal expert of the native tribunals established that the blow given to Capt. Boll had caused concussion of the brain, and that while not sufficient to cause death, it had reduced him to a weak condition, in which he was quickly affected by sanstroke, and had thns acted as a contributory oanse of his death. It is added at least two severe blows on the head were received by Ball after his helmet had been knocked off; subsequently, when already saffering from concussion, he was com­pelled by his assailants to run in the snn.
With respect to the trial of the prisoners arrested for taking part in the outrage, Mr. Findlay informs Sir E. Grey that "the deoision of the Court was unanimous. Premeditation
and concerted action were clearly established 15 or 20 years,, escaped punishment,

by the evidence, as was also the fact that the Hence, it cannot be doabted, a considerable blows which he received aoted as a oontri-1 disrespect for the law was engendered." bntory oanse of the death of Capt. Ball. II Having laid down these grave considerations, am informed that any British jary would j Lord Cromer announces his intention to insti- have found the first six prisoners guilty of tnte further reform*. In fatare no execution murder. In the case of the four men who are will take place before having baen confirmed by under sentence of death, there are no exte- some superior authority, but while averse to nuating oiroumstanoes ; they were held by flogging, he is not prepared to say that in some the Court to be all equally guilty. The Court, apeoial cases it should not be retained. He also expressed its opinion that extreme forbearance proposes that the.terms of the Decree of 1895 and self-restraint characterised the behaviour should be amended in the souse of, for the of the officers. It was only after the latter fQtnre, only permitting punishments of the

had given up their guns that the ohief attaok took place. The villagers oootinued it in cold blood and showed the greatest brutality. Three ot the best-known native advooates defended the aconsed and were given a fall hearing."

The execution, he states in a telegram dated and to defeat the object of those well-wishers of July 4, "could not have been carried out more * Egypt in England with whose general aspira- quickly. I consider that the arrangements were tions I believe myself to he in perfect acoord, admirable and reflect great oredit on all con- j although I may occasionally differ from them oerned." He adds that the "reports published as to the time and method of giving effect to

in the Press have mostly been either false or inacourate, in spite of every facility having been given. The Egyptian, being a fatalist, does not greatly fear death, and there is there fore much to be said for flogging as a jadioial punishment in Egypt."

The most serious part of the correspondence oonoerns the effect prodaoed in Egypt by the attitude of a certain seotion of the Radical party in Parliament. On this subject, Mr. Findlay, telegraphing to Sir E Grey on July 5. uses plain language. "It is my duty," he says, "to warn you of the deplorable effect which is being produced in E *ypt by the fact that mem­bers of Parliament have seriously oallel in question the unanimous sentence passed by a legally constituted Court, of which the best E tglish and the best native Jadge were mem-
bers. This faot will, moreover, supply the lever Sinai Peninsula, has obtained three months'
memorandum by the Earl of Cromer, in whioh

he offars some general remarks upon the Denish­wai incident, and opon its relation to the administration of jastioe in Egypt. Expressing his concurrence in the Bteps taken by Mr. Find­lay, he says, 'Hid I remainel in Egypt, I should in every respect have adopted the same course as that which he pursued. The prisoners had a perfectly fair trial, by a very well-oonsti- tated Court, all the members of which spoke Arabic, in which language most of the proceed­ings were conducted. I consider that the sen­tences, though severe, were j asfc and necessary.

I can see nothing reprehensible in the manner in which they were executed. I may remark that Mr. Machell, who was in charge of the proceedings, is asingnlarly humane man, and is very popular among the natives of Egypt by reason of the great sympathy he has always shown for them."

Then follows a lengthy survey of past judi­cial and administrative methods in Egypt, demonstrating the infamous frequency with whioh, for the slightest offences and by the most subordinate officials, the lash was nsed with severity. This state of things, on the initiative of Lord Dufferin and his successors, has been completely changed, hut with results that our pseudo-humanitarians at home should carefully weigh. "One of the results of the sadden abolition of the 'courbash' was that the people refased to work. I well remember that at one time it seemed that the alternatives would be presented to the Egyptian Govern­ment and ita British advisers of either allowing the fields to remain uncultivated, or else of per­mitting the people to be flogged in order to save them from starvation. It was only the very remarkable skill shown by Sir Colin Moncrieff and his assistants which enabled the Government to tide over the period of transi­tion—a period whioh, I may observe, I think caused me greater anxiety than any other daring my lengthened Egyptian experience. A farther result which ensaed from the imme­diate abolition of the 'oonrbash' was that life and property became insecure. Ot all the Egyptian Ministers with whom I have had to deal, none, probably, had a greater respeot for the law than Nubar Pasha, who assumed office ahoot a year after the isaae of Lord Dnfferin's famous Circular. Nubar Pasha, however, found it necessary to appoint what were termed 'Commissions of Brigandage'—in other words, to introduce martial law.

"Since that time various improvements have been made in the system of jastioe, hut the point to which I wish to draw special attention now is, that gradually the lawless portion of the community in Egypt began to understand that a principle which, so far as they were concerned, was entirely novel, had been intro­duced into the administration of jastioe. It was that no one could he punished for a orime unless he was proved to be guilty. Farther,they came to understand that proof, which would satisfy the Law Co arts, was extremely difficult to obtain, and that in the large maj crity of cases, even when guilt was proved, the punish­ments were far from being severe. The result has been that, in default of adequate proof, a large number of persons accused of crime, who were unquestionably guilty, have, during the
nature of those sanctioned by the penal code.

In conclusion, Lord Cromer says "There is no royal road to progress in Egypt. Any attempt to prematurely foroe Western institu­tions and Western ideas on the people on only have one resalt, namely, to produce a reaction,
the principles which they advocate.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Mijor General Sir F. Wingate had the honour of being received by the King last Thursday.
H.E. Ibrahim Pasha Fuad, Minister of Jus­tice, is expected to arrive in Cairo, on his return from Earope, on the 7th inst.
Jennings Bramly, Inspector
Lieut. F. J. M. Postlethwaite, 1st Batt. King's Own (Yorkshire L. I.), and Lieut. W. F. Stirling, DS.O., 2nd Batt. Royal Dablin Fusiliers, have been selected for daty with the Egyptian Army.
The death occurred in Cairo on Monday evening of M. Elias Ganem, dragoman of the French Consalat9 General at Beyront.

div.head: THE 'EGYPTIAN PATRIOT.' MUSTAPHA KAMEL'S DEJEUNER. A TORRENT OF ABUSE.
div.p: Mustapha Pasha Kamel gave a political dejeuner at the Carlton Hote', last Thursday, at which he expounded his views and those of the party he represents before a small gather­ing. Among the guests were Lord LyttoDj Mr. John M Robertson, M.P., Mr. Boland, M.P., Herr Karl Blind, and M. Suhrawardi, Secre­tary to tho Pan Islamic Association.

In the course of a long and animated address in French, Kamel Pasha declared that many errors and falsehoods were current in England with regard to the Egyptian population. It was said, for instance, that they were fanatical. Nothing could be farther from the troth. If by fanatioism it was only meant that they were Mnssqlmans, then one might as well say the English were fanatics because they, with that great man Gladstone at their head, sympathiz­ed with the Christians of Eastern Earope. The fact was that Islamism enjoined them to treat the Christians with justice and equity, and theirProphet was married to aChristian woman. A National Movement.

The present agitation in Egypt was a natio­nal movement. The Egyptian people were more than ever attached to the principle of the in­dependence of therir territory. Certain people were hypnotized by the financial situation of Egypt, and were astonished that the Egyptians are not happy under the regime of a foreign occupation. To hear them talk one would think that Egypt was a bazaar and not a fatherland. In order to understand why Egyptians deplor­ed the English occupation, one must hear in mind that England has taken from them the Sudan, which was the very soul of their ooub- try, and for which they had made so many sacrifices. Again, the number of English officials continually increased, while that of the Egyp­tian officials decreased.

One of the chief causes of discontent related to education. Before the oooapation, when the Badget of Egypt was far less heavy than at present, the Government schools were free. Under Lord Cromer education was reserved for the children of the rich. The Nationalist Party in Egypt did all they could to remedy this lamentable state of tbiugs. A large number of poor children received free education in national schools supported by voluntary con­tributions.
Administration of the Law.

Then there was the question of the adminis­tration of the law. The numbar of English judges in the courts was constantly increasing, and at the same time Lord Cromer clang to that extraordinary tribanal, the doings of which at Denirhwai had aroused so muoh indignation. In was a monstrous abuse that in a civilized country there should exist a court which had no oode or law, and from whose decisions there was no appeal and no hope of pardon. He de* manded in the name of justice and humanity the revision of the Denishwai judgment before independent judges, such as those of the Mixed Court of Appeal at Alexandria.

With regard to the trial of foreigners for criminal offences, Egyptians were indignant to see so many of them get off soot-free owing to what were called the Capitulations. Foreign prisoners should he sent for trial before the mixed tribunals, which inspired confidence.

It would Dot he forgotten that Egypt de­manded, and obtained, daring the revolution of 1882 a constitution. England annulled the gift, while promising, through Lord Dufferin, to restore it to Egypt in due season. Nothing could secure for Egyptians tranquillity, jastioe, and order hut a constitution giving the people the right of control over the measures of the Government. In claiming its liberty, Egypt did not ask for alms, hat for a reoognized and incontestable right.

At the close of Kamel Pasha's address, Mr. J. M. Robertson ass a red him cf the sympathe­tic interest which his views inspired in those who had listened to him. Mr. R ffiertson express­ed no opinion upon the Denishwai affiir, but said the Egyptian Nationalist Party had the aotive sympathy of a large part of the English people, wno understood their aspirations, and hoped that, with prudence and deliberation, the independence which had been guaranteed to their omintry would heoome an accomplished fact. 1
THE PASHA INTERVIEWED. . In conversation with a representative of ' "The Daily Chronicle," Kamel Pasha made ' the following carefal and considered statement i of the views of his party:— 1

"In the first place," he said, "it is essential to impress upon the English people the simple troth that fanatioism—by which I mean reli­gious animosity—has no existenoe at all in Egypt. The charge of fanatioism is always recurring, and it is invariably trumped up with a view to injuring our people. There is do hatred whatever towards Christians as sneh.
It is too often forgotten that Islam commands tolerance and jastice towards Christians, and the Prophet himself set the example by marry­ing a Christian wife.
Religious Toleranoe.
"And of all Mussulmans the Egyptians are

the most tolerant. The Mohamedans have lived side by side with the Christian Copts for centuries, and men of all nationalities resident in Egypt have recognised our Liberalism in thia respeot. Many EuroDeans have even con­tributed to the rational sohools established among ns by private subscription.

"Since the time of Mehemet Ali we have been extremely prond of onr sohools and, in faot, of all 0 nr intellectual movements, onr newspapers, and so on. We were the first Mussulman people to adopt European civilisa­tion and yet the English seem to regard ns as

nat ves of the Congo ' For 1 eurly a centurj pAdt our young meu have been sent to France or Germany or England for education, and we now enjoy qaite as high a culture as the lead­ing European States. It is absurd to compare ns with Moroocn, or with Lake Chad, as many English people do.

"Ofcouree, we feels natural sympathy with the other peoples of I'lam, just as Gladstone used to speak of the Armenians as his brothel Christians; hut Islam must never be confound­ed with fanaticism among us. Such parties as the Jew baiters or the more violent political and religious sects of Europe couldnot exist in Egypt. Do you suppose that if we had been fanatics the small British army of occupation could have held its own in a population of 12,000,000, or that Lord Cromer ooal<M|ave induced as to believe we were happy and prosperous for twenty-four years ? In face of recent assertions I cannot too often repeat that fanaticism does not exist among us. Egypt is the land of true democracy and Liberalism.We know well enough that fanatioism produces only destruction, but a Liberal spirit works for the progress and enlightenment at which we aim. Tho Denishwai Exooutlons.

"The method of the Denishwai trial and ol the executions has undoubtedly prodaoed a most painful impression on all classes. The nation has never been so unanimous. Even the bitterest opponents of the British occupa tion could not have believed such an outrage possible. All Egypt from the sea to Nubia felt that such treatment was barbarous and unworthy both of ourselves and you. It will not be forgotten. Only one thing oan obliterate the memory of the B^Dg : the Briti h Govern ment must reoognis*ts error aDd change the principles which make such a thing possible All we demand is a system of justice, such ai exists in England itself. No country in the world has snoh a tribunal as thia which Lord Cromer established to decide cases between the British and Egyptians—a tribanal with absolate power, from which there is no appeal. Oar first and immediate demand, therefore, ii the abolition of this tribanal, which we justly regard as a disgrace to civilisation.
No Danger from tho Sultan.

"Many English people appear to think tha it the British garrison were withdrawn wi should fall again under the control of Turkey Such an apprehension springs only from igno rance of our relation to the Snltan.The Sultan as Kbalif of Islam, has a religions inflnenoi over Mohamedans just as the Pope has ove Roman Catholics, and England has sometime used this influence, as at the time of tin Sepoy rising. Bat of political interference from Turkey as one of the Powers there has not been the slightest sign since Tarkey renounced all effective suzerainty by the Treaty of London in 1840. After that treaty Tarkey always respected our independence.8he even refused to send troops into our country when urged by the Powers daring Arabi's movement. Certainly we hope to see Turkey so reformed and renewed that she may become a strong and progressive State, advanoing in civilisation like Japan. Bat no political con­nection enters into the calculations either of Turkey or ourselves ; if for no other reason, because we know that any such attempt wo old unite all Earope against ns both.

"We have no fear of invasion by any Power. Qar country is singularly well situated for defence, and by nature, population, and arms she is now quite able to look after her own in­terests and to protect her frontiers. Programme of National Pa rty.

"The first article in oar programme, there­fore, is natarally the independence of Egypt. Over and over again, in Parliament and in official correspondence, England has solemnly promised to return Egypt to the Egyptians, and it is a promise we never forget. Even apart from that promise, all Egypt would unite in the demand for freedom. Do yon suppose any Englishman would endure the lcs9 of liberty such as we suffer now ? Not one Englishman would endure it.

"As I said, wa have not much fear now of foreign interference, bat oar independence should nevertheless be guaranteed by the Powers^, as is the case with sc many small nationalities^ For onrselves, we demand a free constitution and a truly national Government, bat as long as our debt to Earope continues we are per­fectly willing to accept the financial oontrol of England or of France.
Education Arrested.

"Till this independence comes, we shall devote all our power to extending education among our people. A thing which came as a shock to all Egyptians, and, I think, migh t well shook all civilised people, was England's refasal to grant higher edaoation to the poor in the Government sohools. Before the British occupation all Government schools were free, or pretty nearly free, and tha ohildren of poor parents could rise to the highest positions in the State. In faot, most of the remarkable men of modern Egypt have been ohildren of poor parents.

"But the British system opens these sohools only to the rich, who oan pay the cost of higher edaoation. Lord Cromer has instituted a feeble kind of elementary education for the poor, but no students are now admitted free into the good sohools, and among a demooratio people like onrselves it is rightly regarded as a orime to prevent the poor from sharing in the highest t edaoation. This grievance alone would have , sofficed to make the British Administration
•hated.

"But, above all, it is, as I have said, national à independence and a free Constitution which . we demand. Even Tewfik granted ns a Pariia- l ment, which was destroyed when the British oame. Lord Dufferin promised ns a Parliami j again in 1885, hat nothing has oome of th promises, and now Lord Cromer has
1 the entire power of the State into _
r hands, ar d rules ns like a veritable antoerat b I "Surely our demands are snob as- English
*I people, with their own love of freedom, oan Bunderataad,"

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: Kearsley and Cunningham's Weekly Report Liverpool, July 26.

In Egyptian cotton rather more business has been done this week ; the only changes however in quotations are a reduction of i per lb. in Fiue, and an advance of J per lb. in G. od Brown. Uppers are unchanged. In Futures a fair business has taken place, and the latest valaes are, delivery :
July 9.63Oct. 9.20 Jan. 8.34
Sept. 9 39Deo. 8.42

American Futures —Business this week has again been very restricted, and prices have experienced a fall of 13 points, to day's olosing values being 11 @ 12 points be^ow those of last Thursday. The decline has been chiefly due to weariness at the limited nature ot tho business general pessimistic sentiment, and to considerable uneasiness at the condition of affairs in Russia. The crop reports are gene­rally accepted as favourable, although there have been continued rains over certain portions of the cotton area, which in more lively dr CQmstances would probably have attracted more attention, and which may become serious if prolonged.

div.head: SITUATION IN TEHERAN.
div.p: GRAND VIZIER APPOINTED.
Teheran, August 1.

Mashir El Dowieh has been appointed Grand V'zier. The bazaars are dosed, and business is at a complete stand still. The 13,0C0 refugees at the British Legation persist in their demands for reforms.(Reuter)

div.head: KING AND KAISER.
div.p: MEETING THIS MONTH.
London, August 1.

A meeting between King Edward and the Empetor William has been definitely arranged to take place in the middle of August at Castle Friedrichshof, the residence of the late Em­press Frederick. (Reute>)

div.head: TRANSVAAL CONSTITUTION.
div.p: RECEPTION BY PRESS.
London, August 1.
The Liberal papers consider the Transvaal Conatitotion a fair oempromise.

The Unionist papers, with the exception of the "Daily Mail," are generally moderate in their criticisms, and believe that a British majority is assured if Britishers agree in a oommon policy. (Reuter)
Cape Town, Angust 1.
The ' Cape Times" is of opinion that the Constitution will bring relief to South Africa. The distribution of seats is better than was expected.(Reuter)

div.head: SPORT.
div.p: on last Friday's low level, aridjjys year's loan to 12| discount. There has since been a substantial recovery, and the Fours have im­proved to 73i, the new loan being also steady at Fj discount. Japanese, after being dull, are now firm, and one or two of the issues are slightly higher.
Home Ralls.

There are several additional home railway dividend returns to annoanoe, most of which have been received by the market with satis­faction. The Lancashire and Yorkshire in­creases its rate from 3j to 4 per oent. per annum, this being the best for any Jane half- year since 1900. The South Eastern distri­bution is at the rate of 1 per cent, per annum, against | per cent. 12 months ago. The Chatham pays £2.17 per cent, on its First Preference stock, as compared with 2| per cent. The London and Soath Western main­tains its rate of 4 per oent., and places £20,000, whereas last year no allocation to reserve was made. There was some disappoint­ment that the Great Central is only distributing 2 per cent, on the 1889 Preference stock, the market having expected something like 3| per oent. On the 1881 Preference the dividend is increased from 3 to 5 per oent. The Central London and Waterloo and City dividends remain unchanged at 4 and 3 per cent, res­pectively, hot that of the City and Sooth London is J higher at 2j. The North Staf­fordshire rate is also increased by a similar amount to 4 per oent. The North Eastern announce a dividend of per oent., an increase of and the amount carried forward is increased by £20,651.
The home railway market has derived considerable strength from these returns, and the shares have been actively dealt in. Quota­tions are very appreciably better on balance. Americans.

Some weakness was noticeable in the American railway market as a result of the death of Mr. Russell Sage, but the determined buying of the shares by Wall Street-due to a desire to prevent the Rassian trouble from becoming a bear influence—speedily dispelled the gloom, and for the greater part of the week the tone has been Arm. Union Pacifies have again received aotive sapport, and the closing price to night shows an advance of no less than 5 points at t55 j. Chioago-Mil- waukee also have had a farther upward move, and at 187^ are considerab'y bettter on the week.

It is being more and more reoognised that there is a good futare for these shares, in view of the excellent agrioultnral and oatton orop prospects, and the continually improving state of trade throughout the country. With steadier money conditions, the advance in American railway stocks is bound to be rapid. Egyptians^

There has been absolutely nothing doing in the Egyptian market, and prices have hardly moved. National Bank of Egypt are un­changed at 25|-|, and Agriooltnral Bank at 9 §. The Debentures of the latter' are W little easier at 92|. Daira Ordinary are quoted 16i 17, and the Deferred 96-8, althoagh these quotations are quite nominal. Delta Preference are round about 11}, and Delta Land and Investment, after being 3| buyers, close 3£ Egyptian Edates have been £~good market, and at one time were buyers, bat they close a shade easier at 1}} New Egyptian are 1&, Corporation of Western Egypt j premium, and Union Fonoi&re 6Bank of Abyssinia are still | discount, witnout any business passing. Bank of Ronmania at 10 keep steady, but there is hardly any business doing in them. Daira Sugar are very firm at 5, and Land Banks at 8 Salt and Soda and Egyptian Markets at 1 h and 1} are quite unmentioned. Mining.

The South African market has developed quite a substantial recovery since our last, and although it is doubtless the fact that this is largely due to professional buying, it is none the less satisfactory that the operations should have been so effective. It certainly indicates a complete change of tone, and augurs,well for the future. To dealers,who have had to undergo a long period of depression, the revival this week has been verv welcome, and they have displayed some of their old-time oheerfulness. Most of the shares have steadily advanced, and Rand Mines, East Rands, Goldfields, ModderfonteiDS, and South African Gold Mines are all up about J.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Captain and Brevet Major M. Lowndes, Royal Dublin Fasiliers, on absorption, has been posted to the 2nd Battalion at Buttevant, where he has joined and taken over the com­mand of a oompany.
The reserve squadron of the Inniskilling Dragoons is preparing a draft of men to join the 5th Dragoon Gnards in South Africa.
The home battalions of the King's Royal Rifle Corps have received orders to prepare a large draft to join the 1st Battalion at an early date.

It is understood that the battleship Dread­nought, which is completing at Portsmouth, will be ready for commissioning well within the time allowed by the Admiralty. The armament of the ship is being prepared with unremitting energy, though a little delay has arisen in mounting the two guns of the port side barbette. These are the only big guns that have not been put in position. The two after barbettes have been placed one behind the other, so that the gans of the more forward one will not be able to fire over the other, as has been freely asserted in an offioial description. The gnu fire of the ship when finished will thas be six guns firing ahead and a similar number astern, with eight guns on either beam. The vessel's two tripod masts have been shipped, and form a striking con­trast to the ordinaiy masts of a warship, being somewhat ungainly and awkward in appearance. They are of different sizes, the heavier one being placed amidships. This carries a big fire control station, and to the mast will be attached the gaff for the wireless telegraphy gear. The second mast, which is placed aft, is also fitted with a fire control station.

The Admiralty issaed last night a memoran­dum explanatory of the programme of new constructions for 1905 6,with details not includ­ed in the Navy Estimates for 1906-7. Among the details givea are the principal features of the Dreadnought design, which are now offi­cially issaed for the first time. The battleship's armament is given as ten 12 inch gans, twenty- seven 12-poander quick firing anti torpedo boat gans, and five submerged torpedo tubes. In the arrangement of the armament adopted, six of the guns are mounted in pairs on the centre line of the ship. The remaining four guns are mounted in pairs on the broadside. Thus eight 12-inoh gans (80 per oent. of the main arma­ment) can be fired from either broadside, and four or possibly six 12-inoh gans, or 60 per oent. of the main armament,oan be fired simul­taneously ahead or astern. In view of the potentialities of modern torpedo oraft, and considering especially the ohances of torpedo attaok towards the end of an action, the anti-torpedo boat gnns are separated as widely as possible from one another, so that the whole of them shall not be disabled by one or two heavy shells. Special attention has been given to safeguarding the ship from destruction by underwater explosion. The question of the best type of propelling machinery was most thoroughly considered by the committee of naval and scientific experts, and the memorandum states that there was no difficulty in arriving at a decision to adopt the torbine propalsion from the point of view of sea going speed only. The point that chiefly occupied the committee was the question of providing sufficient stopping and turning power for purposes of quick and easy mance ivring ; and after experiments it was considered that all requirements in this respeot promised to be fully met by the adoption of turbine machinery. The speed designed for the Dreadnought is 21 kuots., and the coal bunker capacity is 2.700 tons. With this amount of ooal she will be able to steam about 5,809 sea miles at economical speed, and about 3,500 at 18J knots, after allowance has been made for bad weather and for a small amount of ooal loft in the bunkers, The total estimated cost of the Dreadnought as revised, including guns, is given as £ 1,797.497.

div.head: CRICKET.
div.p: The following aocount of the Boulao Railway Institute Cricket Club's doings daring July is taken from the All Saints' Church magazine:—

The matches played by the Institute daring Jaly provided nothing very sensational, the chief feature of an uneveutfal month's cricket being the superb all-round play of M. T. Smith. This player has figured as hatsmaD, bowler, and wicket keeper, and has been highly suc­cessful in all three positions. In fact, he was the only one of the old players to do hia self jastice. v Two very capable players have been found in Messrs. E. Seeley and W. Cadman. The former is a bowler of no small merit, while the latter is an extremely useful batsman. Mr. F. de Costa, though not so successful with the bat as usual, captained the team as well as it coaid possibly be done, and the Institute were fortunate when they secured his services. Not once daring the whole month have the R.I.C.C. been able to put a strong team in the field, and ody on one occasion did they win. On the 8th Angnst, Rev. J. T. Boms returns from England, and with him as captain, it is to he hoped that the R.I.C.C. will improve their fairly good position. d

On Friday, 29th June, the oorporals 1st Lancashire Regt. visited Gaesiret Bad^ane The home team batted first and were all out for 83; T. -Smith making top soore with a careful 23. The soldiers made suoh a good start that 33 were up for one wicket, but so well did Smith and Riley bowl that the remaining nine fell for the addition of only 18 rurs, the R.I.C.C. thus winning by 32.

On Friday, 6th Jaly, "C" Squadron, 6th Dragoon Gaards, came down to play the R.I.C.C., and batting first, ran op 165 for only 5 wickets, The Institute have more than once lost a game by bad fielding, but never have they given a more inglorious display than in this match. Catoh after catch was dropped and the throwing in was terribly erratic. The visitors deolared at the abova-menticned score. The institute didn't do much when batting, the only noteworthy featares being the batting of Cadman and the careful play of E. 8eeley, which enabled the Institute to effect a drawx

Another draw was the result of the match with the Military Police. The Railway men, who batted first, gave a good exhibition. The hero of the matoh was T. Smith, who batted for eighty minutes. His inniogs of 54 not out was absolutely faultless. The total was 128. The first six wiokets of the Police fell in quick suooession but by oare- ful play, the two men who were partnered for the seventh, kept in till time, the soore being 85.

The Institute lost to the Sergts. King's Royal Rifls Corps on Friday, 20th July, The Sergts, took first knook and were all ont for 76. E. Se3ley bowled very well indeed, disposing of five baatmen for only 21 runs. The home team only managed to soore 48, the Sergts, thus winning by 28 rnns.

div.head: MOUNT TROODOS,
div.p: Cyprus.

A limited number of paying gne t* can be received by a Lady daring the Sarnmer Months. Cyprus is 24 hours by sea from Port 8aid. Troodo* 6,406 feet abjve the sea is a delightful and healthy place amongst the pice forests where the troops and Government Officials spend the hot season
Terms 2J Guineas per week.
Fvr farther particulars apply to Miss YOUNG,
Nikosia, or to the Editor
Further Particulars.

Position. The pine covered slopes of Mount Troodos where Miss Young has a eamp, are about 6406 feet nlxive the sea ; the troops stationed in Cyprus and the Principal Government Officials live there during the hot season from about June till October.

Routes. Troodos is about 35 miles from the port of Limassol from which there is a good carriage road to Platres 31 in. Beyond Platres the road is good but steep and from that point people often ride on mules for the rest of the journey. There is also an excellent road from the Capital, Nicosia, by which j>ersons going from that side of the Island drive all the way (about 16 miles).
Climate. The climate is very dry and healthy; in the daytime it is delightful ; the nights, especially after the end of August, are often rather cold.

Dress. There is a good deal of red dust on the hills, and ladies should lie provided with washing skirts. White is a good deal worn, but it is advisable to have some brown, fawn, or dust-coloured linen dresses which do not shew dust stains as the washing is not first rate. A warm woollen "coat and skirt" costume is also indispensable.
Rides. There are plenty of delightful rides amongst the hills, but the roads and bridle paths are too steep for bicycles. Mules and ponies can be hired for the
season.
Expeditions. Places of interest to lx* reached on mule or jxmy back are Kykko Monastery, Kalopanaioti, Trooditissa Monastery, etc.
Games. There is a Tennis Club with two good Courts, there are also one or two private tennis and croquet grounds.
Church. An English Church Service is held twice on Sundays at the Regimental Recreation Room.
Water. The water supply is good and the drinking water pure and wholesome..
Money-. Drafts on the Imperial Ottoman Bank and English gold and notes accepted.
By June the railway which runs from Famagusta to Nicosia will be extended to within 20 mile of Nikosia.
